title: Health and Wellness
learningObjectives: Learn vocabulary for health, illness, and medical situations
Understand how to describe symptoms and health problems
Practice talking about healthy habits and wellness
Recognize medical terms and pharmacy vocabulary

sections.title: Talking About Health
sections.content: Health is one of the most important topics in life. When you travel or live in an English-speaking country, you need to know how to talk about health problems, visit a doctor, or buy medicine. This lesson teaches you essential health vocabulary and phrases. Remember: if you have a serious health problem, always seek professional medical help.

sections.title: Body Parts and Common Symptoms
sections.content: Important body parts: head, neck, chest, stomach, back, arm, leg, hand, foot. Common symptoms include: 'headache' (pain in your head), 'fever' (high temperature), 'cough' (to force air from your lungs with a sudden sound), 'sore throat' (painful throat), 'stomachache' (pain in stomach), 'runny nose' (liquid from nose), and 'dizzy' (feeling like everything is spinning). To describe pain, say 'My [body part] hurts' or 'I have a pain in my [body part]'.

sections.title: At the Doctor and Pharmacy
sections.content: When you're sick, you 'see a doctor' or 'go to the doctor'. The doctor will 'examine' you and ask about your symptoms. They might 'prescribe' medicine - give you a written order for medication. You take this 'prescription' to a 'pharmacy' or 'drugstore' to get your medicine. Common medicines: 'pain reliever' (for pain), 'cough syrup' (for coughs), 'antibiotics' (for infections). Always follow the 'dosage' - how much medicine to take.

sections.title: Staying Healthy
sections.content: Prevention is better than cure! Healthy habits include: 'exercise' or 'work out' regularly, 'eat a balanced diet' with fruits and vegetables, 'drink plenty of water', 'get enough sleep' (7-8 hours), 'wash your hands' frequently, and 'avoid stress'. Regular 'check-ups' with your doctor help catch problems early. Don't smoke, and limit alcohol. A healthy lifestyle helps you feel better and prevents illness.

sections.title: Health Conversations
sections.content:
Example 1: DESCRIBING SYMPTOMS - 'I have a terrible headache and a fever. I think I have the flu.'

Example 2: AT THE DOCTOR - 'Doctor, my throat is very sore and I can't stop coughing.'

Example 3: AT THE PHARMACY - 'I have a prescription for antibiotics. How much is it?'

Example 4: CALLING IN SICK - 'I'm not feeling well today. I have a stomachache.'

sections.title: Health and Wellness Summary
sections.content: Remember these key points: Learn body parts and common symptoms so you can describe problems. Know how to ask for help: 'I need to see a doctor' or 'Where is the nearest pharmacy?' Use 'should' for health advice: 'You should rest'. Take care of your health with good habits. In emergencies, call emergency services (911 in USA/Canada, 999 in UK). Don't be afraid to ask for help when you're sick!

keyVocabulary.definition: A sign that you are sick or have a health problem
keyVocabulary.example: Fever and cough are common symptoms of the flu.

keyVocabulary.definition: A doctor's written order for medicine
keyVocabulary.example: The doctor gave me a prescription for antibiotics.

keyVocabulary.definition: A store where you buy medicine
keyVocabulary.example: I need to go to the pharmacy to get my medicine.

keyVocabulary.definition: A high body temperature when you're sick
keyVocabulary.example: I have a fever of 39 degrees Celsius.
I exercise three times a week at the gym.

keyVocabulary.definition: A regular visit to the doctor to check your health
keyVocabulary.example: I have my annual check-up next week.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'I have...' for illnesses and 'My [body part] hurts' or 'I have a pain in...' for pain.
examples: I have a cold/the flu/a fever.
My head hurts. / I have a headache.
My stomach hurts. / I have a stomachache.
commonMistakes: Saying 'I am cold' when you mean 'I have a cold' (different meanings!)
Using 'ache' incorrectly: 'I have a head ache' ❌ → 'I have a headache' ✓

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'should' to give advice about health. Use 'shouldn't' for negative advice.
examples: You shouldn't go to work if you're sick.
commonMistakes: Using 'must' instead of 'should' (too strong for advice)
Forgetting 'should' stays the same for all persons: 'He should rest' ✓
